lexUnit.name: disdainful.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: full of or expressing disdain

sentence.text: ` Tell me you like it , Mademoiselle de Courmont , " he commanded , with a disdainful smile , ` tell me what it is you want .
He folded his arms across his bare chest , the disdainful smile replaced by a stern , fixed stare .
All were rooted in the nineteenth-century stance of the artist as critical outsider , disdainful of the niceties of the bourgeoisie .
All the famous Greek philosophers were disdainful of the artisan , the man who merely made things .
He is a gentleman of complete integrity , ` disdainful of all littleness and meanness " , to whom honour has more importance than life itself .
Reading the highbrow press made people somewhat disdainful towards television , but no more enthusiastic about the press .
In the morning , I paid my disdainful landlady for the use of my room for the rest of the day .
With a last disdainful look , the shoemaker 's daughter turned towards the door .
It sounded to some as though he might be a languid and disdainful aristocrat .
They would simply raise disdainful eyebrows and say what else could one expect of the lower orders ; the Irish ?
Lady Amelia , with one more disdainful glance at Dame Elizabeth , stepped back and closed the door behind her .
Even so , his rather disdainful dismissal of her protests irritated .
Erika , who rather liked the Kiev , was disdainful .
It was a measure of my despair that I dared to be so disdainful .
Could you all sit down " -- here she definitely shot me a disdainful and slightly triumphant look -- on the FLOOR ! "
He was on the receiving end of a look that was as coldly disdainful as any she 'd ever seen .
